@pstamp, @Dillyweed, @ManuPV, @Greyowlsova, @Prognosticating-Beek @Anneinak  Following @ManuPV, I am posting the last time on this question before it closes. Happy to report that my spouse and I passed the 14-day self-quarantine period with no symptoms at all.  It is either that we did not get exposed or did not get infected.  Since we did not get tested for the virus, we don't know the answer.  But it does not really matter because the virus is circulating in Washington state for sure. I have a proposal though.  I am interested in doing a postmortem (pun not intended) on this forecast question.  Specifically I want to know how this small group of forecasters (that worked a lot on the question) performed versus the bigger crowd and why. For those interested, after the Brier scores come out, you can post the scores (yours, median, etc.) to this thread (access from the Closed tab) and write a brief paragraph or two on how/why you did right/wrong, maybe even should have done.   I think we can all learn something from this.n  Thanks.  It's been fun interacting with you all.  See you in other forecasts. Other forecasters that have done a lot in this forecast question are welcomed to participate in this postmortem.

Final update of my forecast, more intended as an excuse to write the comment as a real update. The policy discussion that has resulted in the latest prediction by @Anneinak is really interesting, and I want to go forward with it. Now, it is not clear how many strategies are there for dealing with this (@nigster, @Joseph-Noko), but I can see at least three: 1) Equipment: every one wears a mask, knows how to wear a mask and knows the basic rules of hygiene. This is what has happened in Taiwan and Hong Kong, with the plus for Taiwan that they were really really fast in closing all air traffic with China. This Taiwan model for some reason seems to be forgotten (media influence by China maybe?), but it's ideal, not painful and the economy keeps running. Maybe its success is due to the weather, or more likely by their previous experience with SARS. 2) Confinement: the simple and effective model championed by China. It works, it does not require an endless fight if done properly, but the economy takes a gigantic hit. In the case of China they will take two hits: the month plus of confinement with the subsequent lack of production of anything for exporting and the problem that is coming: with all the West soon in confinement too, what is the point of going back to the factories in Guandong? There are no orders. Now, besides the giant hit in the economy, this strategy needs to be followed to the very end and then it requires to close your borders. You need to be completely sure that the epidemic has been eradicated or you are back to square one, and you better do not go back there because not sure what is going to happen after the second hit. Problems: 2.a) Unless you seal your frontiers and find till the last case in your territory, it will not work in the long term. Then this might be a better strategy for a consumption-based economy like France or India, than for China: how are they going to keep doing business with Africa? 2.b) When and to whom do you open your frontiers? This creates a really interesting prisoner's dilemma scenario: if you are the Schengen area and have finally managed to control this, do you trust the data from China? If you are China, are you totally sure that these guys in Brussels that are not imposing really strict measures have the situation under control? 2.c) Only one undetected case is required to go back to square one. 3) Herd immunity: if you can't win them, join them! This is probably the definite strategy, in the sense that after a bad time (which might feel like an eternity) you are done! Two modalities: uncontrolled (Iran) and controlled (UK?, the Netherlands?) 3.a) the uncontrolled version ends up in a real carnage, but after that you sure get herd immunity and you can go back to your normal life after mourning the dead. 3.b) the controlled version, which is the famous plan proposed by the UK government, but which has big probabilities of not really being implemented because the public pressure against it will mount till incredible levels. This strategy requires an insane amount of coolness. The controlled version is to try to implement the most viable solution to the problem in an orderly fashion. We all know that some of us will die in this scenario, but somehow we keep totally calm and just proceed with it. One can try to prioritize that the children get infected and then pass it, so you remove one of the most effective vectors of the virus. Then you go with the teenagers, people in their twenties, etc. The result is theoretically a small number of deaths in comparison with the large number that you could have, but you can do it without blowing away your economy, particularly if you want to do business with every one. It also gives you a wonderful biological weapon against the countries that decided containment, as you just need to reintroduce your newly endemic virus into enemy territory. Maybe this could be the next move of Iran against Saudi Arabia.  But then what can I say, for my age group the prospect of a 5% probability of hospitalization, though merely 0.4% of death still do not look that great. I am not itching for being intubated, even if my chances of dying are minimal. Any more thoughts @pstamp, @Dillyweed, @dlaiocean, @Greyowlsova, @Prognosticating-Beek ?

15 Mar 64.3k (+20%) As in [1] I calculate average and sample stddev of ln(1.25), ln(1.28), ... , ln(1.2), which come out to ~0.196 and ~0.024 respectively. To break into top bucket we need ln(G(16 March)) + ... + ln(G(20 March)) > 0.544 Assuming G(t) are iid again, expected value of that sum is 5*0.196 = 0.98, and stddev is sqrt(5)*0.024 ~ 0.054. So to land under 0.544 would be 8 stddevs below expected value. Going all in on top bucket. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/991609

Situation Report #55 is out ( https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200315-sitrep-55-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=33daa5cb_6 ). There's been 10,982 new cases since the last, which is a 12.4% gain over the previous report. That brings the now-21-day* average rate of daily increase to +13.4%**. So, still, the WHO count will exceed 200,000 on March 20th even if there is no increase in the number of daily new cases. In fact, it requires that the remaining time see an average daily DECREASE of more than 5%/day in new cases to avoid hitting 200,000, which is incredibly unlikely. Anyone who has even 1% in the "Between 100,000 and 200,000, inclusive" segment at this point is saying that they consider it to be reasonable to expect a sharp and steady decline in new cases (even though the Worldometer indicates we should expect 15,000+ new cases in the next WHO report) over the next few days.  I think that's clearly wrong. *21 days is the baseline I'm using because, when I started this line of analysis, "two weeks ago" looked to me like a good round number of weeks to start a post-Wuhan phase from. **There is accumulated round-off error in this number, but I'm too lazy to dig it out, and the number's there just to sanity-check the later-given necessary daily rate of increase for reasonableness.

Using a small sample set AND averages can be helpful and dangerous, but without a more comprehensive modeling tool, I hopped over to Excel.
The final outcome will be limited to our WHO situation report on 20 MAR. That said, based on their numbers, I was curious as to if there was a trend to the new case DoD delta. Understandably not an exact linear curve but suggesting exponential growth, I took a quick and lazy average of last week.
So in flattening the curve, peaks I hope to have accounted for preventative measures as well as lead and lag in reporting. Do I want to call it with confidence? No. But in exercising an abundance of caution, I'll say that if this were my job and lives were at stake, I'd go with my math. To put a fine point on it, I'd venture to say that we'll hit 200k by or before 19 MAR. Even to double/dummy check my work, I looked at the DoD delta of total cases. That trend appears to be close to linear. So again, flattening to the current rate as a minimum, we appear to trend towards 200k before the 20th.

Per the Johns Hopkins site, there are presently ~163k cases, which means that adding 36k gets us to 199k before this question ends. My estimate of 70% in the +200k category is based on a continuation of the current exponential (vice lineal) trend. If there's an add of 5% per day (as opposed to just a lineal 8k), then we cross the 200k mark just before time runs out,.

GJ forecasters have been forecasting on the possibility of a pandemic for many years, year after year.  On Jan 6th, I read in the NYT about 59 cases of a "mysterious flu-like illness" in Wuhan, China that seemed to be linked to a wild animal market.  I thought to myself, "Uh-oh.  This could be it.  Wild animals.  China.  Flu-like."  It fit the model.  I didn't want to think it. Denial isn't just a river in Egypt. What do we do when we see a bear with cubs?  We approach the cubs to take a picture.
How do we react when someone tells us someone has died?  We say, "No!  You're kidding."
How do we react when we're told that smoking will kill us?  We wait to quit until we start to cough a lot.
What do we do when the river is rising?  We watch it until it undermines a corner of our house because it would be so much trouble to move.
How do we react when told we have an illness that is incurable?  We go to Mexico for a cure.
How do we react when a gigantic wildfire is headed our way?  We watch the flames & smoke from our homes.
How do we behave when someone ferociously attractive is in our arms?  We take risks.
How do we react when there's a pandemic and we're asked to social distance?  We think "I'll be ok; everyone looks healthy". I thought about decreasing social contact for about a week before I actually began to do it.  It's not just that we don't understand exponential growth, we don't respond well to threats and dangers.  We either don't recognize the danger (the wild bear), can't accept the truth (of death), procrastinate (about quitting smoking), are lazy (not wanting to expend the energy to move), are frozen in fear (as a wildfire approaches) or think that the laws of statistics and biology don't apply to us. We wait.  We wait until the very, very  last minute. Unfortunately, this almost always results in us being unable to maximally mitigate the impending disaster. Therefore, I expect that what we do will be far less effective than if it had been done earlier, and if the necessary infrastructure had been in place (like ventilation machines, N95 masks, etc) long ago.   Hence, my high forecast for 200k +. Others far, far better educated than I have done the math.  My thanks to  you all. @ManuPV, @Greyowlsova, @Dillyweed, @dlaiocean, @jtrommel, @pstamp, @Prognosticating-Beek

There's an "exponential growth" theory about. I'm coming at this from a different angle but the answer is the same. If you look at the chart on this website: https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6, you should see two spikes in the data. Today's leap may be thanks to exponential growth, or it could be an outlier thanks to the random distribution of chance making today a particularly bad day: for example, 5 people in 100 could be infected every day, but out of those 5 per day, maybe 2 are tested on day 1, 3 on day 2, 5 on day 3, and maybe on day 4, the 5 untested carriers plus the 5 infected on day 4, all get tested. Even when growth is flat, the number of new cases can follow a different growth function. Indeed, the number of atual infections can fall even as the number of tested new cases rises! So my question is, is today just a bad day or is today proof of the exponential growth theory?  So one of two things can happen, the rates of new cases follow this spike and maybe in 3 or 4 days we breach 200,000, or, the numbers fall again to an 8-9,000 day range. I personally expect the median for the next 7 or so days to be 8-9,000, but, it actually doesn't matter in a sense: because of this spike or new wave, to reach 200,000 by the 20th, we now only need a daily average of 9,000 new cases if the total number of cases for the 14th ends at 155,000. Worldometer has the number of new cases at 155,792 right now. If the number of cases today ends at 160,000, we just need 8000 new cases a day. The number of new cases yesterday was 7499. Another bad day and even if the rate falls, 200,000 will be an easier hurdle whatever the growth function.  I am not totally sold on the exponential growth theory, and I think, like the seasonal flu, the growth curve follows a logistic function. There's a fascinating article and it shows where you get with an exponential function and where you get with a logistic function. I did the sums for an exponential function as well starting from Jan looking forward and the numbers were obscene and way too aggressive. This article makes a better case: https://medium.com/swlh/novel-coronavirus-simple-analysis-and-predictions-6338e7870a43. And here's an earlier case for exponential growth: http://www.renewamerica.com/columns/cherry/200126.  As I said, at this point it doesn't matter if it's logistic or exponential because the spike in the last 24 hours, could either set a trend for a daily average or be an outlier, either way, the daily average needed to get to 200,000 has fallen to something within reach. Redoing my calculations [1] with new numbers from today [2]. Will make my reasoning more explicit so others can spot errors more easily. Below are cases in world minus China and South Korea ("ROW") since 6 March, with increase relative to previous day: 06 Mar 11.2k (+25%)
07 Mar 14.3k (+28%)
08 Mar 17.6k (+23%)
09 Mar 21.3k (+21%)
10 Mar 25.3k (+19%)
11 Mar 29.6k (+17%)
12 Mar 36.2k (+22%)
13 Mar 43.8k (+21%) Now ROW needs to 2.54x in order for us to reach 200k. This means an average daily growth of ~ 14.2% (I get this by doing (2.54)^(1/7) - 1.) Let's model ROW growth each day t with a random variable G(t). In the end we are interested in whether G(14 March) x G(15 March) x ... x G(20 March) > 2.54. In order to use standard theorems I will turn the above into a sum by taking logs, so I will be interested in the variables ln(G(t)) instead, and want to know how likely it is that ln(G(14 March) + ln(G(15 March)) + ... + ln(G(20 March)) > ln(2.54) ~ 0.932. For simplicity I assume the G(t) are all independent and identically distributed, so I will drop the t. I think this is reasonable while the absolute number of cases is quite small in each ROW location.  The average and sample stddev of { ln(1.25), ln(1.28), ... , ln(1.21) } are ~0.197 and 0.0265 respectively, so our best estimates of average(ln(G)) is 0.197 and of stddev(ln(G)) is 0.0265. Hence the expected value of the sum of 7 copies of ln(G) (from 14 March through 20 March) is 7*0.197 ~ 1.379, and the stddev of that sum is sqrt(7)*0.0265 ~ 0.07.  Hence a growth of < 2.54x, meaning ln(G(14 March) + ln(G(15 March)) + ... + ln(G(20 March)) < 0.932, would be over 6 standard deviations below the expected value. Which seems extremely unlikely; less than 2% likely by Chebyshev [3]. De-extremizing to 95% to account for simplicity of this modeling. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/990771
[2] https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200313-sitrep-53-covid-19.pdf
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chebyshev%27s_inequality#Probabilistic_statement

Testing is happening at differing speeds globally: South Korea, with a population of 51 million, is testing 10,000 people a day, having tested 230,000 people so far, whereas the US has tested 11,000 people despite a population of 327 million, as examples. Given the bottleneck in testing, or, in the case of countries such as the US, a seeming reluctance to test aggressively, the real figure is likely to be much, much higher.  In terms of the reporting, it becomes difficult to get a sense of where the math is headed. Yesterday's situation report (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/) had the global number of cases at 125 048 confirmed (6729 new from the previous 24 hrs). The 11th had 4620 new cases, the 10th had (4125 new) new cases, the 9th had (3993 new cases, etc. The trend is upward and gradually -at least in terms of our expected range. If we assume a dramatic increase from today till the 20th and say each day will on average see 10,000 new cases, then, we move from 125 048 confirmed cases to something under 200,000. The more days pass without reaching 10,000, the greater the chance that on the 20th there will be less than 200,000 people infected. The limiting factor will be the bottleneck in testing centers. Countries like the US, or regions like sub-Saharan Africa and South America will not be able to grow their testing capacity appreciably within the next week, and those countries conducting testing, I expect to still have significant bottlenecks. Of course, something could happen to allow them to widen testing and move aggressively but...

Big growth today. Doing some calculations with new numbers. Now assuming China + South Korea have largely contained the spread, at least for the next 8 days. So I focus on other countries, which I call ROW (note that on my previous forecasts and in the media at large ROW just means world minus China). ROW stands at 36.2k today. It needs to reach 111.1k for us to reach top bucket. This means 3.07x growth. For context, here is ROW growth over the past few days (compared to the previous day): 06 Mar 11.2k (+25%)
07 Mar 14.3k (+28%)
08 Mar 17.6k (+23%)
09 Mar 21.3k (+21%)
10 Mar 25.3k (+19%)
11 Mar 29.6k (+17%)
12 Mar 36.2k (+22%) We have 8 days to go; what % does ROW need to grow per day to do 3.07x in 8 days? Well, 3.07^(1/8) ~ 1.15, so with 15% daily growth we will get there. We have been well above that for the past week; the geometric mean of the growths above is +22% daily. Moreover, if we take the average and standard deviation of { ln(1.25), ln(1.28), ln(1.23), ln(1.21), ln(1.19), ln(1.17), ln(1.22) } we get ~0.1985 and ~0.0285 respectively; and it turns out that even if we assume daily growth TWO standard deviations below the mean --- i.e. a growth of e^(0.1985 - 2*0.0285) --- it still comes out to 15.2% daily growth, which is enough to reach 200k, as discussed. What could drive deviation from the average scenario, which easily reaches 200k? Pushing the average down is the big lockdown in Italy (2nd largest number of cases). However, the lockdown happened on 9 Mar, so it will only (or mostly) slow down the appearance of cases that would be diagnosed after the question deadline. I read that the incubation period for the virus is ~2 weeks, so most everybody that will be diagnosed in the coming 8 days got the virus before the lockdown. Similarly for other countries that may do future lockdowns. Pushing the average up is the fact that less testing was probably done over the past week in ROW, than will be done in the coming week, as countries wake up to the threat. Using the weakest possible estimate (Chebyshev's inequality [1]), the odds we would see growth above (mean - 2*stddev) are 87.5%; adjusting for qualititative factors above it should be at least 90%. If instead we use a normal distribution to approximate the aggregate growth in the next 8 days (central limit theorem), the odds of reaching 200k are 98%. For now, due to noisiness of data, I will tone it down to 85%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chebyshev%27s_inequality

I'm creeping back into the 200+ camp for two reasons:
1) It's now in 118 different countries, an exponential rise is inevitable.
2) Now that it's in the US and more Americans are tracking it closely, we're getting a better appreciation for how fast it spreads in an open society (i.e. one that's not on lockdown), even when the populace is reasonably well-informed. The increased interest has also caused an greater interest in the numbers, so there's an increased incentive to not underreport the numbers of infected. 
All that to say I expect to see exponential jumps in the coming 8 days. But, I could be wrong.

Updating because yesterday I had a huge brain fart --- I kept saying out-of-China (ROW) cases needed to 3.2x to reach 200k, but they needed to 4.2x. Might as well do the calculations again with today's numbers. It seems China (or at least China's reported numbers) has contained the disease, so I focus on ROW throughout. There are 80.9k cases in China so ROW needs to get to 119.1k to reach top bucket. There are 32.8k cases in ROW now so ROW needs to 3.63x. The more qualitative factors are still: US just began testing more widely (so more reports), South Korea and Italy are in heavy lockdown (so less transmission). Looking at the reports from past several days, it does seem South Korea has largely stopped spread. Just a week ago the growth rate was >12% new cases daily, now it's below 2%. So let's take Korea's 7.5k out of the equation, now we have 25.3k "doubling-liable" ROW cases. This means they need to 4.41x for the top bucket to be realized. In contrast, Italy has been seeing ~20% new cases daily for the past ~10 days, and today's report was no different. So I don't take them out of the equation. According to the horrible map on the first page of [3], most cases are spread throughout Europe, plus Iran. I've not heard of any other country besides China + SK + Italy doing massive lockdowns so I doubt the spread will slow in any other countries. According to [4] the doubling time in ROW has been 4-5 days throughout March; but if I take out SK, who have seen a big slowdown, that means the doubling time ROW minus SK must be LESS than 5. So it looks as if we're right on the edge: we need 2.14 doublings (4.41 ~ 2^2.14) and the remaining 10 days are between 2 and 2.5 doublings. THat would suggest 50/50 between the top two buckets. However, another bottleneck is the tests themselves: cases can only be reported after the appropriate test comes back positive (I assume?), and I imagine e.g. Iran can't scale the testing quick enough for this question. I would wager the same of India --- their current reported cases, and especially the growth, seem ludicrously low. Finally, some country may start a heavy lockdown in the next few days. So I adjust from 50/50 to 60/40. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/988149

2) Outside of China we have 33.5K cases and 10 days left
3) For reaching 200K cases, we need a doubling time faster than: 10 / Log[2, 119K / 33.5K] ~ 5.5 days 4) Key question: which will be average doubling time in the next 10 days? At this moment is somewhere in between 4 and 5 days, but it is slowly decelarating. Which means that we are really in the limit between the two buckets. Tricky. Going back to my first model [1] I get: 0, 0, 0, 42, 58 Going to my second model [2] I get: 0, 0, 0, 50, 50 if I use 5.5 plus/minus 1.0 days doubling time. Yet this looks optimistic. Running my second model [2] with 5.1 plus/minus 1.0 days doubling, gives me 0 ,0 ,0, 34, 66, which means that I am really sensitive to my guesstimate of which is going to be the average doubling time. Number reported as of 9 March 2020 is ~110k. Doubling period of 3-4 days, >2 such periods to go. Seems a sure bet. Except, China seems to have contained it, and they have 81k of those 110k. (Or at least, they are reporting numbers that makes it seem that way, and that is what matters for this question.) This leaves the "doubling-liable" population at ~29k. Still, we have only 90.4k cases to go before 200k, and that is merely ~3.2x 29k. For contrast, 11 days is 2.75 doubling periods (if doubling time = 4 days), leading to a naive exponential estimate of 2^2.75 ~ 6.7. To phrase it differently, how long would the doubling period have to be, for us to not reach 200k? We're only allowed to grow 3.2x (a little less actually) and that translates to "1.68 doublings", i.e. 3.2 ~ 2^1.68. Since we have 11 days left that would require the doubling period to be 11/1.68 ~ 6.5 days (a little over actually). In contrast, estimates of the doubling time outside China are currently in the 4-5 range, have been ≤6 since Feb 20, and have been ≤6 on 88% of days this year [2]. From another angle, my understanding is testing just got unblocked in the US, so that will probably lead to an uptick in reports in the short run. On the other hand, Italy just completely shut down (drastic quarantine measures) so that should drive doubling down in Italy. For now I will call it 50/50 between top two buckets, though in my heart I think I am being too conservative and the top bucket should be higher. Situations on the ground at US epicenter.  
Sharing this with @Greyowlsova @pstamp @Dillyweed @ManuPV @Prognosticating-Beek I live 12 miles from the US covid-19 epicenter (or maybe even ground zero).  The epicenter is an acute care nursing home in a suburb of Seattle in the state of Washington.  About 3 to 7 residents died in that facility in a typical month.  But since 19 Feb, 26 residents died, 13 of which were tested positive for covid-19.  We don't know whether the other 13 deaths were related to the virus.  It is recognized that the virus existed in that facility probably several weeks before the first death.  The virus has spread outside the facility already.  Right now, there is little, or no, attempt to track the people exposed to the virus.  At this point, it might be impossible to track.  (The US is a very mobile society due to the extensive use of cars.  One example is the 12 miles between the nursing home and where I live is considered to be a very short distance.  I go to that suburb once or twice every week.)    Right now, there is no attempt for massive testing for the virus.  This explains why the fatality rate in the US is so high right now.  There is definite no plan for massive lock down of communities.  For one, it is probably too late as the virus has likely spread widely (due to mobility of the population).  For two, it is difficult to do in the US culture. To minimize exposing the population to the virus, many companies In this area have mandated employees working from home.  Universities are holding virtual classes.  But primary and secondary schools are still open.  Some cultural events and conferences are cancelled or postponed.  But so far, few sports events are cancelled and there are still plenty of spectators.  This is another oddity in the American culture - sports come first.   People are coping.  Restaurants and movie theaters are half empty.  Traffic is much less.   We are running out of hand sanitizers and toilet paper in stores.  Some people are staying home due to fear, but some people just carry on with their routines.    How is this going to end in the US?  Right now it is in the accelerating stage.  I don't see a lock down coming, unlike China, SK and Italy.  Even with a lock down, it is too late to contain the virus as it has spread already.  My hope is that the virus outbreak is seasonal, just like SARS and the common flu.  The other hope is that the fatality rate for covid-19 is much lower than the 3.4% reported so far - this number is driven mostly by reported cases from China which some people believe are way under reported.  If the under reporting is by a factor of ten, then the fatality rate will drop to the level of the common flu. One last interesting tidbit is that in the state of Washington, the 19 covid-19 deaths generated lots of publicity.  But at the same time, 79 people in the state died from the common flu and nobody gives it any thought.

In the spirit of Tetlock’s ‘Superforecasting’ I came up with the following subjective estimate of the multiples and probabilities [Multiplying Factor {Prob}] that the public data could be off at this point in time:  [1x (20%), 2x (40%), 3x (20%), 4x (10%), 5x (5%), >5x (5%)].  Will be interesting to see if there is indeed a difference when future researchers look back at this.

Well, this morning's freshly backed data: 25.5K cases outside China growing exponentially, 106K cases worldwide. We need 94K new cases to reach the 200K+ mark, and this requires: Log_2 (94K /  25.5K) ~ 1.9 doublings Having 12 days left, we need a doubling time above 6.4 days to avoid hitting the 200K March. Alternatively we can use the official 7 of March WHO data, in which case we will need a doubling time below 5.9 days to avoid hitting 200K, which is the same estimate as with yesterday's worldomoter data. This indicates that the official 8 of March WHO data will also converge to 6.4 days. In the last few days the doubling time has decelerated indeed, from 3 days one week ago to 4 days now. If the deceleration continues at this rate we will double again in 5 days and then in 6 days, reaching 200K by 19 of March. But I don't really know if this is going to stand up, it might be overly optimistic. Assuming that the average doubling time from here till March 20 is 5.5 days with a standard deviation of 1 day, this puts the 6.4 day mark at 1.1 sigma's away from becoming a reality. Surprisingly the daily cases outside China are still doubling every 3.2 days.  The surprise part of it is the 3.2 days and not that it is doubling. As of today, it will require ~120k additional outside-China cases in the 13 remaining days for the worldwide total to reach 200k.  If the 3.2 days doubling time holds, 120k will be reached in 7 days.  If a doubling time of 9 days is used starting today, it will just reach 120k in 13 days (20 March).  These two calculations bracket the problem.  By 20 March, 200k cases will be reached even using a 9 days for doubling time (starting from today).  I don't see any doubling time less than or equal to 9 days coming any time soon.  So it is very likely 200k will be reached.  So I officially join the pessimistic crowd.  :)  @Greyowlsova @pstamp @Dillyweed @ManuPV @Prognosticating-Beek

Last WHO situation report (#45) was 95,333 cases with 2,241 new.  Anyone who thinks there's even a 1% we won't pick up 5,000 cases by March 20th is insane. ( https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/ ) The only question is, will the number of cases grow fast enough that in 15 days, we'll pick up another 105,000.  Well, to do that, we'd need to average 7,000 cases/day.  In the last five days, we've gone from 1753 new cases/day to 2,241 new cases/day.  That's 28% growth, which is quite respectable.  Forward 5 days that would move us up to 2,868, then five days from that 3,672, then five days from that 4,700.  Which is to say, even at the end of the time period, we wouldn't have as many new cases/day as we need to average over the next 15 to reach 200,000.  We'd need to have a rate-of-increase of roughly twice what we've seen over the last five days to reach 200,000 by the 20th. So, I'm going all in on "Between 100,000 and 200,000, inclusive", and I'll stay there unless and until the rate of growth in new cases suddenly spikes.

I estimate we'll hit 200k around March 14. That number has been steadily moving forward for the last couple of weeks: March 20, March 18 and now March 14. However I think (and I hope) it turns out to be much later. Also the error bar is highly skewed with a much larger likelihood of error on the long side.  My model assumes exponential growth that slows by about 50% between now and Mar 20. My model is simplistic and only works in the exponential growth phase: new cases each day outside of China modeled as x% of the trailing 7 day average number of new cases where x is based on the recent average + a 2%/day decay. x has averaged 213% in the last 2 weeks and 135% in the 2 weeks before that. It needs to average 147% or higher to hit 200k by Mar 20.  I expect that some time between now and Mar 20 we're going to get a big jump from catch-up reporting in places that have been systematically under-reporting such as US, Iran, North Korea, India, etc.  My strategy is going to be to adjust up and down each day based on whether the daily new cases pushes the 7 day average above or below 147%.

I have updated my forecast to include data outside of China. Since my last forecast the Rest Of World cases are near a tipping point and are presently estimated to reach ~160,000 - in addition to the present ~85,000 cases in China. However, by March 20, the global cases will very likely exceed 100,000. I have adjusted upward, and anticipate the highest likelihood between 100,000-200,000 cases by March 20.
To explain as I did in my first forecast: I am using the Logistic Distribution function to model S-Curve (cumulative) cases. This is the system dynamic of disease propagation as explained by many including Dr. John Sterman of MIT (see Business Dynamics, and the original work in System Dynamics by MIT Prof. Jay Forrester). The function is fitted to a line using the GRG algorithm in Excel Solver. However, this method is not without difficulty as an optimum point is not provided by the Logistics Distribution function. Regardless, multiple iterations of solutions can provide a reasonable estimate.

Not directly related to the question, but just musing... Why was China willing to sacrifice 50% of GDP for 2+ months to turn this around? => I believe they recognized that if ICU cases exceed their ventilator capacity the death rate would become 10+%. They were past the tipping point in the Wuhan area and needed to ensure that they didn't pass the tipping point elsewhere. What's the equivalent tipping point in the US? 
There are roughly 70,000 ventilators (or about ~20 ventilators /100,000 population) in the US. (extrapolating from this Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21149215). Perhaps half of these are NICU units and i assume those can't be used on adults. So for the purpose of this analysis we have ~10 ventilators per 100,000 population. Based on data from China, about 20% of cases require ICU and half of those require a ventilator. So we could have up to able 10x as many cases as ventilators before we start running out of ventilators and the death rate goes up sharply. So our tipping point would be when we hit about 100 cases / 100,000 population, or 0.1% of the population in a given area.  Example: in Washington (state) with 7.5M population the tipping point would be roughly 7.5k cases. My estimate is that we're at about 1,200 cases today in Washington. [Dislaimer: that's my rough estimate, almost all undetected; take with a huge chunk of salt. My thinking is here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/982052 ]. If so, and if the virus continues to spread at it's current rate, then we will be at the tipping point in Washington in 15-20 days based on a doubling period of 5 days. Around March 20. My guess is that the government is going to get really draconian really fast when we start approaching a point where there aren't enough ventilators.

I'm expecting to see a continued big increase in coming days. I'm convinced true case numbers are already way higher than reported (see below). Anyway that's not the question, it's how many will be reported.  Here's why I think true case numbers are much higher than reported:  1) Iran: official tally is ~50 deaths which implies about 2.5k infections roughly 15-20 days ago. (2.5% death rate, average of 14 days to die from onset of serious symptoms + 5-10 days incubation period). With doubling period of 5 days that would imply that the first cases arrived in Iran in mid January. It also implies roughly 20k active cases today. That may sound nuts, but when you consider that 3 senior govt officials are sick that we know of, and one has died, that gives a sense of the magnitude. Also if you look at the dozens of cases that have spread to ~10 nearby countries, that's an indication of the magnitude in Iran as well. Will they ever be reported? probably some will and most will not. But they will cause the disease to spread and keep the numbers worldwide going up.  2) However ... unofficial reports (credible to me but ultimately uncertain) are that deaths in Iran are over 210 at this point, so you can multiply all that by about 4. 80k cases in Iran.  3) However ... Here's another, independent way of estimating those numbers: Bahrain has reported that ~2,300 people have returned to the country from Iran since Feb 1. (https://www.timesofisrael.com/bahrain-threatens-arrest-of-travelers-from-iran-untested-for-virus/) Of those 310  have been tested and 38 are confirmed. Let's assume that the 310 were in fact the most sick of the bunch and every positive case was detected in which case we get a rate of 38/2,300. That's 1.65% of all travelers from Iran confirmed. That's a minimum of course because only 310 cases were tested, but anyway.... There are 80M people in Iran. Let's limit it to just those who live in Tehran and Qom where most cases are reported. That's ~10 M people => Let's say our sample of people traveling to Bahrain is representative of infection rates in Iran, then 1.65% x 10M = 165k people infected in Iran. (Note that there is a lag because these people came over the last 30 days and probably represents a mix of a lower percentage early in the month and higher percentage later in the month. Plus a growth factor for an average of 15 days). Who knows, but still that's a reasonable minimum estimate. I'll call it 2-4x to account for these factors (i.e. 1 or 2 5-day doubling periods), so between 165-600k people infected today in Tehran and Qom by this method. Plus however many are in the remaining 70M population outside those areas.  4) Similar analysis in the US: We heard about 2 new cases about the same day they died. The numbers are a bit fuzzier, but Let's just start with the 2 deaths in Washington. Same math => ~75 infections 20 days ago => ~1,200 today again assuming a 5-day doubling period. Same thing in California (but based on cases, not deaths) gives something like 100 cases in Vacaville and surrounding areas.

Taken at face value this gives a doubling time of 3.1 days, which could be translated into an R0 of 5.0 using a really braindead comparison method, i.e. taking Exp(lambda * T0 * R0) = 2 for the original estimation of R0 = 2.4 and doubling time T0 = 6.4 days, then replaying the numbers. WHO 1 March report shows 87k infected cases worldwide.   Lets step back from our models and speculations and do a consistency check. On 1 March, there are 87k infected cases worldwide (including China). There are 20 days before the closing of this question. China has been reporting 300-400 daily new cases for several days. If we assume that the daily cases do not change much, 20*400 gives 8k. The worldwide aggregate daily cases are still on track for doubling in 3 days. SK appears to be slowing down, but other countries can easily pick up the slack. Lets be conservative and assume the worldwide cases stay at 1000 per day for another 19 days. This gives 20k. So 85k+8k+20k = 113k. This estimate does not use models, just a couple of simple reasonable (and conservative) assumptions. Unless you believe that worldwide cases will collapse in the next 20 days (which I deem very unlikely), the total infected cases will be over 100k by 20 March.  On the other hand, unless the doubling of the cases continues for over two weeks, the total cases would not go over 200k.  I consider this case unlikely.

As of today (March 1), exponential growth outside China continues and so as before the questions are: 
1) how long will exponential growth continue at a rate to hit 200k by March 20?; and
2) can reporting keep up with exponential growth? Here are top the arguments I see for continued exponential growth through March 20: 
1) the population outside of China is 5-6x larger than inside China so this has lots of room to run
2) * the rest of the world cannot provide a strong, unified containment measures like in China: virtual house arrest  and restrictions on travel of >50% of the population for over a month is just not feasible in much of the world
3) * there is no longer a single containment focus, but multiple hotspots and untracked spread in the community Here are arguments I see for sharp slowing of growth before March 20: 
4) For whatever reasons (weather, genetic, cultural, etc) R0 proves to be much lower outside China
5) * Despite lack of coordinated government action in some places, individuals will react in ways that reduce R0 such as staying home, avoiding public events, etc. All of the above are likely to be true to some extent. However I suspect one or two will dominate over this timeframe and my guess they are #2, #3 or #5, which I have starred above.  Making this more quantitative, the doubling period for total cases outside China has been:
Last 2 weeks: ~4.3 days
Last 4 weeks: ~4.8 days
Since beginning: ~3.9 days
Rate required to hit 200k by March 20: ~5.0 days or lower So if the doubling period slows to >5 days then it we won't reach 200k by March 20. My guess is that's more likely than not based on the factors above especially #5, so I'm calling it 80/20 odds that we won't reach 200k. I'll continue to watch the doubling rate and if it stays below 4.5 for the next week then maybe adjust up.   Here's another way of slicing the data: Below I've categorized countries (or rather "jurisdictions" if you like since some of them aren't really countries) based on COVID-19 case growth and I draw these tentative conclusions: 
1) The places where COVID-19 has spread the most and the fastest are moderately cold at this time of year (Iran, northern Italy, S Korea, China, Japan and international conveyance (off Japan).
2) The places where there have been repeated exposures and relatively large numbers of cases including confirmed local contagion but where it doesn't seem to have taken hold are generally warm: Singapore, Hong Kong, Australia (in summer now), Taiwan, UAE. Is that a pattern that has meaning? I have no idea. It could make sense given that SARS-CoV-1 had rapidly declining survival rates in droplets and on surfaces at higher temperatures, lower humidity and more sunlight.   So I think the evidence suggests we should expect slowing growth between now and March 20 with successful local containment in a few places plus new clusters popping up elsewhere, mostly in colder places. Finally I have found a simple relationship between R0 and growth rate.  In an article "Estimating the Basic Reproductive Number (R0) for African Swine Fever Virus (ASFV) Transmission between Pig Herds in Uganda" [1], the authors wrote down such an equation (referenced to a book "Infectious Diseases of Humans" which I did not read but you can read it in Google Books [2]). The equation is    R0 = 1 + (T / td)*loge2  where T is the infection period and td the doubling time.  Using the doubling time of ~3 days in the infected cases outside China, and an infection period of 12-14 days, R0 is 3.77 to 4.23.  (Note that I am treating the outside-China cases as a black box.  It is impossible to break the cases down to individual countries.  So one can think of the R0 estimated as an effective R0 for the world). The latest update from WHO (29 Feb) shows the daily cases are still on track to a doubling time of ~3 days.  The question is when will the exponential growth start to taper off.  (Humans have a tendency to assume the rapid changes going for a long time.  A good example is the economic growth in Japan in the 80's.  At the time, the US was talking about Japan taking over the world.  Well, its growth tapered off eventually.  Similar thinking happens for the growth in China several years ago). So when will the exponential growth of the infected cases taper off?  It happened for the Chinese cases.   @Greyowlsova you used a logistic growth model for the Chinese cases.  I envision two ways to do this.  One is essentially a curve fitting to existing data (fit the data to a logistic growth curve).  This is relatively easy to do AFTER the data start to taper off.  This methodology is also similar to the S-curve fitting and "long-tail" distribution for daily cases fitting used by several forecasters. The other way is to make an assumption (or educated guess) on the turning point of the curve.  Which one did you use?  If it is the latter, we can use the information to make an educated guess on the turning point of the future outside-China cases. From yesterdays WHO report: "The diagnostic landscape of this outbreak is changing quickly. The first COVID-19 cases were detected using genomic sequencing, but multiple RT-PCR commercial and non-commercial assays have since been developed. As the international case load increases, there is an urgent need to rapidly scale up diagnostic capacity to detect and confirm cases of COVID-19. WHO has taken a three-pronged approach to enhance global diagnostic capacity for the COVID-19 virus:
1) Developing a WHO network of 15 COVID-19 reference laboratories with demonstrated expertise in the molecular detection of coronaviruses. These international laboratories can support national labs to confirm the COVID-19 virus and troubleshoot their molecular assays.
2) Strengthening national capacity for detection of the COVID-19 virus so that diagnostic testing can be performed rapidly without the need for overseas shipping. Existing global networks for detection of respiratory pathogens are being utilized including, notably, the National Influenza Centers that support the Global Influenza Surveillance and Response System.
3) Ensuring ongoing test availability. WHO has procured a commercial assay (manufactured under ISO:13485) with strong performance data and shipped to over 150 laboratories globally as an interim measure for Member States requesting support. The main goal is to strengthen global diagnostic capacity for detection of the COVID-19 virus. Support is now also provided to ensure the quality of testing through the implementation of an External Quality Assurance mechanism.
Public health efforts are targeted at both interrupting further transmission and monitoring the spread of COVID-19. As reports of asymptomatic cases increase, the need for reliable serology testing is becoming more urgent. There are a number of groups working on this and developments are being monitored."

I've taken a fairly close look at the growth of new cases inside and outside China. Chinese cases have been decreasing in recent weeks, and averaging less than 500 over the past five days. New cases outside China have the opposite trend, increasing with the emergence and growth of hot spots (S Korea, Italy, Iran), with an average of just under 350 over the past five days, but on an increasing trend. If new cases outside China follow a similar trend to the early growth on new cases in China, I expect them to be at about 900/day by 20 March, while Chinese cases should drop to ~ 100/day, or a rough total of ~ 1000/day at the close of the challenge. Total new cases have averaged ~ 870/day over the past five days. I'm guestimating that daily new cases will hover between about 850 and 1000, +/-, between now and the end of the challenge, or maybe an average of ~ 950. With the current total (as of yesterday) at 81,109, and 23 days to go, I get a most likely total on 20 March of about 103k, +/- a few thousand.

I'm very confused by the many forecasts that project <100,000 cases (though am very open to having the rationale explained to me).  It is, of course, very difficult to predict how this epidemic (pandemic?) will progress, but let's take the inside view and look at what has happened with this virus historically:  On January 27th, the WHO reported 2,798 cases - today (almost exactly a month later) there are north of 81k cases worldwide, for an increase of 29x. Let's assume for a second that the number of new cases in China drops to zero tomorrow - the rest of the world is today roughly where China was ~30 days ago (2,918 infected). Is there a reason to believe we won't see a similar increase in the number of infected elsewhere in the world (even allowing for the fact that there are only 23 days left on the questions close date vs. a full 30)? It is my understanding that if anything a) China may potentially have underreported their numbers and b) was able to implement draconian containment measures which would be very difficult to achieve in the rest of the world. Add to that the fact that the U.S. has almost certainly underreported its current number, having tested <500 people and it's hard for me to see how the risk in this question is towards anything but the upside...

There are already over 80000 cases according to Johns Hopkins (https://news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-brazil-confirms-first-covid-19-case-in-south-america-11943575), and this more than doubling by the end of March just seems almost inevitable to me. That said, there is still a slim probability that it won't break 200k, or even 100k, and I'm hazy on the various reporting systems.

From the reported infected numbers, it looks like the outbreak in China is under control.  Its daily cases have reduced from a peak of ~4000 to ~500 on 25 Feb.  But infected cases are started to ramp up outside China, notably Iran, South Korea and Italy.  On 25 Feb, the daily cases outside China are 75% of those in China.  Brazil just reported its first case today, and it is having its carnivals.  It is going to spread in South America where the health and political systems are not as advanced as developed countries.  And we have not heard from Africa yet, other than the case in Egypt. I am convinced now that covid-19 is going to spread to the rest of the world.  Over time it could top 200k infected cases. But with 23 days to go before 20 March, I don’t think it will get to that number.  It takes time to ramp up and in most countries and they don't have 11 million people concentrated living in a city. Using my model based on mainly the Chinese lab-confirmed cases (because over 95% of the cases are from China, so far), the infected tapers off to 66k by early March.  Add the 17k CT scan cases yields 83k.   It is difficult to do an estimate for future cases outside China since it is just starting to ramp up.  If I use a flat level of 1000 cases per day and multiply it to 24 days left, it yields 24k.    Add this estimate for the above 83k yields 107k, just above 100k.  This is likely an underestimate considered the uncertainty in the newly infected areas.  But giving the short time left for this question, I don’t think it is a factor of two off. Despite increasing efforts at containment and prevention, the Coronavirus continues to grow to almost pandemic levels. In an initial forecast 2 weeks ago, I assessed a 29% chance the number of Wuhan Coronavirus reported cases would reach between 25,000 to 100,000 by March 20, 2020. At the time, the virus's growth rate, based on WHO daily situation reports, reflected an average of 979 new reported cases a day. Since the initial forecast, the daily global growth rate has increased to 1,802 reported cases a day, even though new reports in China have decreased. Deaths outside of China, and Asia, have also increased despite stronger prevention and containment efforts by national public health officials. The number of reported cases on February 11, 2020, reached 43,103, with the projected total of cases reaching 80,289 by March 20, 2020. As the growth rate rises, and without successful intervention, I now foresee the number of reported cases growing to 126,183 by that same time. As test kit supplies run low in China, the accuracy of reporting in the region is unreliable, making it likely many more cases are not yet detected. WHO representation states the world is not ready for a global outbreak and encourages nations to sustain measures for quick action on isolation and social distancing. The revised forecast suggests a 75% chance the number of reported cases will remain between 100,000 and 200,000 by March 20, 2020, with a 25% chance it will grow higher if measures are sustained.

The former case is likely to over-estimate COVID-19 cases (as other flu strain symptoms overlap greatly with COVID-19).  That said, there are reported 'surges' in new cases of COVID-19 (mostly in S. Korea and other Asian countries); while in the U.S. case are growing, but relatively slowly (low numbers of new cases). Lastly, the R-naught (the infection reproduction number where all members of a population are equally susceptible) for COVID-19  = 1-3 which is less severe the SARS (R-naught = 3-5). So, I will slightly adjust my forecast to reflect both the 'clinically diagnosed' cases and the apparent 'surges' in S. Korea and elsewhere (and assuming a low to modest spread in the U.S. and other Western nations)

Responding to @cmeinel @ManuPV and @dlaiocean who have made helpful comments recently:  I think the details of what mathematical model you use (S-curves or gaussian; binomial vs exponential) isn't the first-order issue here. Instead it's the logic of deciding whether to think in accelerating or decelerating terms. If we accept that the Chinese are getting their arms around this then something like one of the first would apply; outside of China it's clearly exponential: accelerating. The problem is that human brains don't deal well with exponential growth. It isn't intuitive to talk about hundreds of thousands or millions when current data is hundreds and thousands.  One aspect of this problem that I find particularly challenging is that there is an unknown gap between WHO-reported numbers and the underlying reality on the ground. This gap is potentially large and more likely to be a large under count than an over count. Arguments for errors that undercount: It's easy to miss, not test or not to report large numbers of cases; on the over-reporting side there are only false positives. Under reporting could easily be a factor of 2 to 10 in some places versus over-reporting which is presumably limited to something like 10%.  Here's one example: There are ~7 or so deaths confirmed in Iran but only ~43 confirmed cases with no known linkage back to China. 7 deaths / 2.5% death rate implies that there were something like 250-300 cases *14-21 days ago* (which is roughly how long it takes to kill you). It seems probable that there was an index case from China and a subsequent super-spreader event yet to be identified. The ~7 confirmed deaths represents a minimum accounting of all COVID deaths and could be higher. Since the doubling period outside China has been running at 5-7 days implies that a reasonably conservative estimate for the true number of cases in Iran is something like 1200-3000 today. I assume under-reporting in this case is due to some combination of a) limited lab testing capacity, b) low political appetite to announce numbers in the days leading up to a Presidential election; c) most cases are presumably still asymptomatic or showing just mild flu-like symptom and showing up at random hospitals so effectively undetectable; and d) there may be a tendency to not want to self-report cases until symptoms become severe which as we know takes like 1 week after onset of symptoms. Given the history in other places, there seems a reasonable likelihood that subsequent super-spreader events will happen (or have happened) when these people start getting admitted to hospitals.  There are other examples: is a similar discrepancy in the numbers for the Chinese prison system. Many countries have few or no reported cases (like Iran until last week) and those too suggest unreported cases: e.g. India, Congo, Pakistan. (Note that there are also countries like the US, England, Japan and Singapore with apparently much more successful attempts to stay on top of accurate reporting of the disease.)  So the challenge as it relates to this questions are "Will there be catch-up reporting that is accepted by the WHO at some point before March 20? And if so by how much?" Clearly the large majority of these cases will never be counted, but the question is how many will?  Like you and others my best solution is to just follow the data, which shows consistent growth outside of China with a doubling period every 5-7 days. That alone will get us over 100k by March 20 even with zero new cases out of China.

Latest numbers [1]: 
-77,794 cumulative confirmed cases (1,025 new) and 2,359 cumulative confirmed deaths (112 new). Projections [2]: 
-1) Projection based on average # new confirmed cases of past two days shows that confirmed cases will exceed 100k on ~March 15 but will not exceed 200k as of March 20.
-2) Projection based on average day-on-day percent growth in confirmed cases of past two days shows that confirmed cases will exceed 100k on ~March 13 and will not exceed 200k as of March 20. Overall, these simple projections in confirmed case numbers show that the case number on March 20 will most likely be between 100k and 200k, but closer to 100k.  It should be noted that there is a lot of uncertainty at the moment, given that opposing forces are acting on the number of new confirmed cases. Daily confirmed cases are rapidly dropping off in China, but new clusters of cases are also rapidly appearing outside of China [3]. It is difficult to assess how these opposing trends counteract one another - hence, I have used a simple linear projection approach that assumes these two opposing trends will more-or-less cancel out. However, the bulk of uncertainty is on the upper tail end given that new outbreaks have the potential to cause an exponential growth in the confirmed case count. The numbers of infected cases reported by China and WHO have been very confusing.  I have looked into untangling the mess and want to share the findings with the community.  The findings have some bearing on this forecast (for me and maybe others). Confusing data:
China has changed their criteria on their counting the infected cases several times.   Before Feb 14, only the laboratory-confirmed (a more accurate methodology) cases were reported.  From 14 - 16 Feb, China added a category of confirmed cases (the so-called clinically-confirmed cases) for positive CT lung scans.  On 17 Feb, China started to add the combined (laboratory and clinically confirmed) cases and called them “confirmed cases”.  WHO followed China’s reporting, resulted in a jump of 15384 (mostly clinical cases) to a cumulative total of 71429 confirmed cases.  (It should be pointed out that CT scans do not provide an accurate indicator of the presence of Covid-19.  The reported number 71429 is likely to be an over-count, probably by a large margin).

This procedure was followed for 3 days until 20 Feb.  From 20-21 Feb, China decided to report only the lab-confirmed cases and included those in the cumulative count.  After two days, it changed again by adding clinically confirmed cases.  This time it is even worse because it does not report the number of clinical cases separately; they just appeared mysteriously in the cumulative total. The above findings are based on the WHO COVID-19 situation reports [1] which derived the Chinese cases based on official Chinses sources.   All these details are probably too much for the average readers.  The bottom line is, though, there is a 15000-17000 WHO-reported confirmed cases that are clinically confirmed cases.  The WHO 20 Feb reports states that “Some previously reported clinically diagnosed cases are thus expected to be discarded over the coming days as laboratory testing is conducted and some are found to be COVID-19-negative. “  Based on China’s flip-flopping on this issue, it is not clear that this will happen. For the modeling, I decided to remove the clinically-confirmed cases from the data (to the extent that I can).  Then I add the 15000-17000 cases back to the modeled results.  This would probably an over-count as not all the 15000-17000 cases will be laboratory-confirmed cases.  Gleaning from the data that are available (14-16 Feb), the daily laboratory and clinically confirmed cases are about 50-50. Now the modeling:
My previous forecast [2] is an attempt to model the decreasing daily confirmed cases, using a Gaussian curve.  It assumes the same up and down slope.  Recent data (I am using only the laboratory-confirmed cases) indicate that the down slope of the curve might is slower than the up slope.  A function with a longer/fatter tail is needed.  I used a Beta distribution function to do that.  
My model suggests that the cumulative confirmed cases taper to 65000 in early March.  If I add the entire 15000-17000 laboratory cases to this total, it will yield 80000-82000.  This is below the 100000 threshold in one of the forecast baskets.  If I only added half of the 15000-17000, it will yield about 74000.  The result is based essentially on the China cases as they are overwhelming larger than the rest of the world right now.  We all understand that Covid-19 appears to be spreading worldwide.  But the infections have been relatively slow, unlikely the rapid ramp-up in China.  The dense population in China and the missteps of the Chinese government early on in the outbreak have probably contributed to the rapid rise.  With lessons learnt, I believe that the spreading will be much slow and the total cases will not be much larger than those in China for the duration of this forecast.  Shout to those that might be interested:  @ManuPV @Prognosticating-Beek @Tetbury @Nik @Dillyweed @Aglor @bobrown [1]  https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200222-sitrep-33-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=c9585c8f_2
[2]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/964700

I have updated my forecast to include data in the past six days. The reduction in cases per day has been dramatic. This is not consistent with the Logistics model. The progression is not characteristically smooth. This pattern existed immediately before the Chinese NHC revised its cases to include non-RNA test observations. Again, given the scale of the outbreak, the data suggests that the NHC is not able to collect all of the case information and report accurately. As such, further adjustments seem likely. However, given that the current data suggests the third tipping point of the Logistics model has been achieved, it is more likely that <100,000 case is possible. My model presently forecasts ~80,000 cases total, but again I anticipate under-reporting. I have adjusted downward, but anticipate the highest likelihood between 100,000-200,000 cases by March 20.
To explain as I did in my first forecast:  I am using the Logistic Distribution function to model S-Curve (cumulative) cases. This is the system dynamic of disease propagation as explained by many including Dr. John Sterman of MIT (see Business Dynamics, and the original work in System Dynamics by MIT Prof. Jay Forrester). The function is fitted to a line using the GRG algorithm in Excel Solver. However, this method is not without difficulty as an optimum point is not provided by the Logistics Distribution function. Regardless, multiple iterations of solutions can provide a reasonable estimate.

New update:  1) Official growth in China (which is still telling us a political story, not necessarily a medical one) can be adjusted to various S-curves, saturating at about 90K for symmetric S-curves (hyperbolic tangent, lorentzian) and at about 130K for Gompertz. Notice that this approach has systematically subestimated the possible number of cases  (I have been checking this day after day, though there have been a couple of days after the redefinition on cases in which there was overestimation instead), though maybe this time a symmetric sigmoid curve will hold. What are your thoughts on this @dlaiocean ? 2) Growth outside China seems to be doubling every week (yet a lot of credit should be given to that giant Petri dish love boat, the diamond princess), but assuming some control measures it could optimistically be contained in the 5-10 K cases region. 3) The several manifestations of the outside view will result in a log-normal distribution, where different versions of the plus/minus 1-sigma brackets (the 68% probability band) will yield similar results. Examples: 3.a) From 100K to 1M: 0,0, 6, 21, 73
3.b) From 100K to 200K: 0, 0, 13, 71, 16 which after averaging, will yield a very similar estimation to that of @Dillyweed , @Tetbury or @KitsonJ , that is, basically the bulk of probability lies in the two biggest buckets. 4) To summarize, most of the probability will concentrate on the last two buckets. Right now, on the absence of official outbreaks in Cambodia or in a few African countries  which offer visa-free travel to Chinese citizens (ain't no epidemic if we don't run tests), I will put more probability in the 100-200K bucket than in the 200K+ one.

I'd like to address some confusion about the reported numbers: people are citing 71K cases (from unofficial data) while WHO in February 16 update cites two sets of numbers right now – 51,857 total and 69,267 (68,584 in China + 683 outside) cases. After the update for today, WHO will have the second number close to 71K as well – bureaucratic channels are always slower. The difference between numbers is that China now includes clinically diagnosed cases - lesions in both lungs by CT plus other symptoms – in their count while WHO at this point recognizes only laboratory confirmed cases - confirmed by DNA testing (e.g. PCR), but for the big picture reports clinically diagnosed cases as well.
I should stress that BOTH sets of numbers are INCORRECT as they both differ from the real numbers of infections: laboratory confirmed cases do not include clinical cases that were not confirmed by PCR because of the lack of kits, samples, logistics, personnel… And clinically diagnosed cases may include cases NOT caused by COVID-19 - pneumonias with other etiology. And both numbers will not include mild cases when people did not get to the hospital and recovered at home or otherwise ignored, deliberately or not.
So BOTH reported numbers are just approximations: most probably, the higher number is closer to the truth. Now there are two trains of thought here on GJOP. I’ll simplify both – please don’t scold me for skipping nuances. 
The minority one is that if you look at the trends of daily new infections, the outbreak is getting under control regardless of what sets of numbers you use. Using logistic models, the outbreak will be defeated relatively fast if the current preventive measures are sustained.
The prevalent opinion is that the REAL numbers are so underestimated that the official numbers, even the 2nd set, do not reflect the true numbers and COVID-19 is spreading fast, though in reference to official counts, its spread may be slowing somehow. And there are of course forecasters in between two views, incorporating some from the 1st, some from the 2nd.
Media supports mostly the 2nd view. Even CDC or WHO officials sound more like the 2nd view, warning about the dangers of COVID-19 and pandemics.
My opinion is that the officials have no choice, but to inflate the dangers: if not people get lax and all the preventive measures may fail and COVID-19 will spread further. And who is going to be blamed? Yup, them not sounding the alarm.
Media of course is prone to sell apocalypses (who would read them otherwise?!), citing rather experts who forecast doom than calm.
The deal breaker is the number of deaths. This number is the hardest to fudge. They started going down predictably after the new cases started going down with a certain lag.
Please bear in mind, at the end, GJOP will base their resolution on official WHO number, not on a model for REAL numbers even if the latter ones make more sense.
My opinion, just wanted to help make sense of all that. I may be mistaken and do not pretend to know The Truth. Sorry for the long post.

I am updating my forecast based on the new information on cases through today.  In order to do this I had to make several adjustments to my logistic SIR model: 1) I created two models - one for PCR confirmed cases and another for PCR + clinically confirmed cases.  The model is the same but the results are a little different 2) Assuming that the final scores will be based on the public PCR confirmed + clinical cases, I've gone with that results 3) To run my model for the PCR+Clin, I took the ratio of the new #s from China for the PCR+Clin/PCR and get an average ratio of about 1.3.  I then "back calculated" the trend of total cases from the beginning to build my forecast curves.  Note that this is at best a 'kludge'.  I've not seen anyone change case definitions in the middle of an event and to do so raises questions about the underlying 'real' number of cases.  I suspect we won't know those answers for some time. 4) Assuming I haven't made any terrible errors or crazy assumptions my results are as follows: Peak Cases occurred as originally forecast on or about Feb 5th.
Total PCR+Clin confirmed Cases are estimated to be: 70k [58k, 84k], Mean [10th%, 90th%] So my probabilistic forecast remains about the same.  I will revise again as needed.  One point to mention is the reliability of 'clinical diagnoses'.  Assuming that the PCR diagnosis is the 'gold standard', it would be typical for a clinical diagnosis to exhibit sensitivity and specificity at much lower levels, eg. Sens = 75%, Spec = 75% to make things even.  Assuming that the prevalence (or prior) in this population is high (eg, 60%), then one can estimate the Positive Predictive Value (PPV) of such a diagnosis.  This is equivalent to the probability that an individual clinically diagnosed with Covid-19 actually has the disease.  For the example I just did, the PPV is only about 80%.  Depending on the actual values of Sens, Spec, and Prev, the results can vary but this means that the actual count of clinical cases that turn out to be actual Covid-19 are potentially 20% lower than what is stated.  This of course assumes that we are getting the best, most current estimates and that there is no systematic bias in what is being reported.  Just something to keep in mind.

I am using the Logistic Distribution function to model S-Curve (cumulative) cases. This is the system dynamic of disease propagation as explained by many including Dr. John Sterman of MIT (see Business Dynamics, and the original work in System Dynamics by MIT Prof. Jay Forrester). The function is fitted to a line using the GRG algorithm in Excel Solver. However, this method is not without difficulty as an optimum point is not provided by the Logistics Distribution function. Regardless, multiple iterations of solutions can provide a reasonable estimate. At present my estimate is ~140,000 cases (after the recent change in reporting).

There is a reason why WHO has not changed their way of counting - firstly, real REAL numbers are never known as the reported cases are practically always an underestimation: e.g. as a rule, mild cases slip through. Secondly, what is most important, are trends and sudden addition skews them. The truth is that the prevention measures are working and the reported number of new cases per day started waning. And yesterday, we got another confirmation of that - number of deaths per day was less than previous day. Which was expected, deaths are lagging diagnosis of new cases. And they started going down right on time - average time between first symptoms and ARDS is 8 days and here the difference between the peak of new cases and deaths was very close - 7 days. Adding more deaths hid that. Furthermore, I think that the Chinese added huge numbers for political reasons - to assuage their own populace that the government does not hide the real numbers AND the moment for that was exactly when they (the government) got convinced the outbreak shows signs of containment. So soon they can proclaim their successes in the fight over COVID-19. So I do not change my stance with new numbers from China as my logistic model gives the highest number less than 54K (95% Upper CI limit). Adding another 14-15K to this is significant, but is well within the limits. If the new guidelines increase proportionately number of new cases, still there is plenty of room.

The spike in reported cases is merely an artifact of improved reporting. Knowing that China is becoming more fact based in its reporting is good cause for raising our forecasts. However, this does not mean that the rate of spread of the epidemic is increasing.

Official reports started on Dec 31 2019 - so by this time, the official outbreak will be 80 days.  As of the 11 Feb 2020 the WHO had 43,103 cases - so in 42 days these are the recorded cases. 
It is widely considered that China is withholding data and potentially there are x10 more cases inside China which reported 42708 on the same date. So 99.08% of reported cases are inside China - meaning that there is no dramatic contagion outside of China.  Large parts of South East Asia and Africa are not reporting cases - meaning that the numbers are wrong.  This means we can discount the first two probability options above and whilst the numbers sit between 25,000-100,000 we know that the current numbers are low and reporting will catch up as we get better at global detection.  In terms of the adaptive system then, we are going to get better at detection and reports will grow over the next 36 days remaining. There will also be retrospective cases added. This pushes the WHO totals up meaning we should start from the assumption around 45,000 today and growing - and think about incubation periods.  We will get better at stopping the spread and dealing with contagion and public health cases - this pushes the rate of contagion down. So if we were to double the cases we would have 90k (applying the Copernicus principle). But this seems unlikely - because of the drop off rate. So it is very very likely to fall between 25,000 to 100,000. With the only real chance of going over 100k, being if China changes reporting methods (it won't because that is highly political and a challenge to the regime) or the WHO change the way they count cases.

After today's spike of 15K new cases, now we really have to update the predictions. First, a fundamental distinction to be made: A) How many actual cases there will be by 20th of March?
B) How will there cases be (purportedly) underreported? Regarding A), this goes as in my previous posts: the question is how many doublings there will be. Then assuming the doublings are normally distributed, we will get a log-normal distribution. Using different estimates the results usually look something like: If 50K to 0.5M is the 2-sigma window (+lower cutoff of 60K) : 0, 0, 15, 22, 63
If 50K to 0.8M is the 2-sigma window (+lower cutoff of 60K) : 0, 0, 12, 26, 52 Estimations which can be improved by adapting the 2-sigma windows to the new situation. B) There is a problem with the data set coming from China. Today we have seen a dramatic change in the new cases. Reasons for this are: B.1) The new policy for counting cases in Hubei (CT-scan seems to be enough, owing to the lack of enough testing kits) (UPDATE: YES)
B.2) The WHO observers have been in Hubei for a pair of days, which left the Hubei and central Beijing government with the option of being corrected by the WHO or correct themselves. (UPDATE: MAYBE, but unlike)
B.3) The central Beijing government wants to use the Hubei government as a scapegoat. (UPDATE: YES)
B.4) Maybe the Hubei government wants the central government to look bad. (UPDATE: NO)
B.5) The aliens did it. (UPDATE: NO, probably) (UPDATE: Hubei government out, central government sent Ying Yong to clean the mess, whatever that means. New standards maybe necessary as probably there are not enough test kits and most pneumonias are likely to be caused by the new virus.) Yet actually there is no way to know what is actually happening, because things in China are not transparent. Till yesterday the narrative was: everything is under control (as you can see from the numbers), we will go back to work soon. This narrative has not necessarily changed. A brief chat with some of my more "officialists" friends indicates that they really still believe that things are under control outside Hubei. A brief chat with friends that are suspicious of the government usually ends with serious admonitions of "please do not go back to China anytime soon". Well, we do not know what is actually happening with the reporting, but till yesterday symmetric sigmoid curves, like the hyperbolic arctangent and the logistic curve, saturated at 50K cases, while non-symmetric sigmoid curves, like Gompertz, saturated at 75K. Today this saturation numbers are 75K and 150K, respectively. Both the arithmetic and geometric means are above 100K, which indicates a high chance that even official Chinese data will cross the 100K line. Besides, if no one has noticed, there is a doubling of non-Chinese cases every seven days or so. With five weeks till 20 of March, this will leave us with 16K extra cases. But probably it will be much less as measures to contain it are expected to happen. Yet their efficacy could be limited owing to the large number of countries affected. Let's say 5-10K, putting a lower punch line of 80-85K cases, too close to the boundary of the 100K bucket. For simplicity, instead of doing the math, I'm simply going to move the probabilities between the buckets: I will remove a 10 percent of the below 100K bucket and move it to the two high buckets.
