New update over my previous prediction[1]: the policy of the communist party towards reporting has changed. Before there was the suspicion of moderate levels of underreporting, but from now on this is going to increase. The reasons for that are very well explained in [2]. Which means we have two problems to solve: A) How many cases there will be by 20th of March?
B) How will local officials underreport these cases? Regarding A), the current data seems to saturate at about 50K cases if we fit it to some S-shape curve. Yet this is a lower anchor only. The higher anchor depends on the number of doublings. With four doublings, which is perfectly possible, we will end up in 0.8M cases, in which case I would end up with a log-normal probability distribution that fills the buckets in approximately this way: 0, 0, 15, 34, 51 (after moving the excluded probabilities from the lower buckets to the higher ones). Other estimates could be from 50K to 0.5M, giving a geometric mean around 160K cases. If we assume this covers 98% of the probability space, we will end up with the following buckets:  0, 0, 19, 21, 60 (where the skewing towards the 0.2M+ bucket happens once we ignore the lower buckets). It is interesting that the second, more conservative estimate, gives a higher estimation for the last bucket. The reason is the lower variance, curiously. Regarding B), it all depends on which is going to be the line in the sand for each province. Now local authorities will have strong incentives to underreport their numbers while taking quarantine measures that are more stringent than other provinces' (sort of contradictory, but welcome to the "superior-to-the-west" Chinese political system). For a first estimate, I will think that on aggregate this reduces the probability of the last bucket by 2/3's (that is, we go from 51% to 17% for the last bucket). If we distribute the probability equally among the first two buckets that have not been excluded yet, we will get: 0, 0, 32, 51, 17  But do not forget a last factor, the expansion of the coronavirus outside China. Right now, for a quick estimate there seems to be a doubling of non-China cases every week or so, which leave us with six doublings or a factor of 64. This could translate into another 10-20K cases, maybe 30K, depending on the evolution, rising the lower anchor to 60-70K. This will reduce the probability of the first non-exluded bucket maybe by a six percent (difficult to estimate), which will  go to the next two bucket. Thus I will end up with: 0, 0, 27, 53, 20  which will be my temporary estimate for the time being [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/962324
[2] https://www.chinalawblog.com/2020/02/chinas-coronavirus-solution-more-government-control-trumps-more-medicine.html

https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(20)30068-2/fulltext "An important determinant of whether or not 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) will ultimately cause a global pandemic is its ability to become established upon its importation to a new country. Cases of 2019-nCoV infection have so far been reported in 24 countries, yet little human-to-human transmission outside of China has occurred.
The key quantity governing whether or not 2019-nCoV can establish and generate a sustained outbreak on arrival in a new country is the reproduction number, R, which represents the average number of individuals that each infector will transmit the virus to. If R is greater than 1, sustained transmission can occur; if R is less than 1, then chains of transmission will simply stutter out.
In the ongoing outbreak, assuming an R of 2·2, as reported by Li and colleagues,1
then just over half of infections must be prevented to bring R below 1. This might be expected to be challenging if 2019-nCoV can be transmitted when infectors are not symptomatic.
However, there is little evidence to suggest presymptomatic transmission of 2019-nCoV.2
Even if 20% of infections are occurring because of presymptomatic infectors (a level roughly halfway between the respective values for severe acute respiratory syndrome and influenza viruses,3
which is likely to be an overestimate), then 80% of infections would be due to symptomatic infectors. Because only slightly more than half of infections need to be prevented to bring R below 1, effective isolation of symptomatic hosts alone should be sufficient to prevent sustained outbreaks of 2019-nCoV outside China.
Of course, detection and isolation of symptomatic hosts is not always carried out effectively, and detection is challenging when symptoms are mild. Therefore, efforts to counter presymptomatic transmission might sometimes be merited. However, when implementing such measures (eg, the UK's isolation of passengers returning from Hubei, infected or not), the substantial cost to individuals who might not be carrying the virus should be considered carefully. With fast isolation of symptomatic individuals alone, including self-isolation of those with mild symptoms, sustained outbreaks outside of China can be prevented."

Screen first with CT scan - if you have lesions in both lungs, you are confirmed by PCR (DNA) testing. It looks like that is good news for the outbreak.  The daily increase of infected cases peaked at 3924 on 5 Feb and has been decreasing since (3722, 3205, 3405 and 2672 for 6-9 Feb, respectively) [1].  If this trend holds up in the next couple of days, the outbreak is similar to the SARS outbreak - peaking is followed by a rapid decrease in the daily infected cases[2].  In my previous forecast, I used a piece-wise linear model (several linear trends each holds for 2 weeks) to predict the total infected cases by 20 March.  However, with a turning of the curve in sight only 8 days from the start of the exponential rise, it is clear that the previous model is way too pessimistic.  A much shorter time scale is needed. A new model is developed, taking into consideration of the turning of the curve.  I fitted a Gaussian shape curve to the daily infected cases using the available data.  Then I project the infected cases until it tapers off.  The cumulative curve is very similar in shape to that from the SARS data.   Based on the data (up to 9 Feb so far), the curve tapers off at 60,000 by 20 Feb.  This is much smaller (and sooner) than my previous forecast [3].  I will be updating the model parameters each day as the new data come in. [1]  https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/
[2]  https://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/en/

The last few days of data have been confusing and internally inconsistent. The number of current severe cases (patients in ICU) has continued its exponential path. However current confirmed cases have suddenly slowed or declined in Hubei and in all of the other chinese provinces combined (individual provinces generally have small enough numbers that it's tough to make sense of the data). Same for international. Here's are two modifications of my thinking since last time: 
1) The Chinese government has taken a new approach: they are no longer tolerating negative news coverage of the outbreak since around Feb 3-4. This coincides with the number of reported Chinese confirmed cases dropping. My guess is that they are no longer testing as many people and/or aren't reporting the results. Note that this is interesting in terms of the actual wording of the question. Will the WHO rely on estimates or only official Chinese data?) 
=> My conclusion is that we cannot say that the outbreak has suddenly been contained as some people seem to think. That may turn out to be true, but I don't think we can conclude it from the data. I think it is continuing to grow but at a slower pace. However, I do think that the change in Chinese policy makes a lower official WHO result much more likely and this is what's driving my change above.  2) the R0 of ~2.2 still seems pretty solid at least so far. However, case studies suggest that this value seems to be made up of a small number of super spreaders (like the dude on the boat) and a whole bunch of people who infect just 0-1 people. 
=> My conclusion is that this may be easier to contain if that's true. Government and social changes can and will reduce the number and severity of super spreader events. 3) For whatever reasons, this epidemic has not taken off yet outside of China or even outside of Hubei. Is this due to genetic issues? Logistics? Social issues? Government response? Luck? I don't know but it seems like good news.

Saw an inflection in the new numbers of both deaths and new cases. So, looked at sigmoid functions. Inspired by @BayesianChimp, did my own logistic model and was surprised how low numbers came out: between 41K and 52K, with 46K as estimate, very close to BayesianChimp's . Due to my complete ignorance, tried Gompertz function (it was introduced to assess human mortality). It gave me higher numbers: 113K as estimate between 92K and 135K. Yes, I behaved as a kid in a candy store. Still, looked like overkill - it is characterized by slow start and that's not what we had here. I should admit - I went from the 1st bucket (it cannot be that far from SARS!) to the last bucket (pandemics!) and now to the middle one (look at the models for outbreaks and data!). Clearly, I'll be hit by my scores. But the run has been fun. And I may have learnt something new along the way...

"The epidemic doubling time was 6·4 days (95% CrI 5·8–7·1)...If the transmissibility of 2019-nCoV were similar everywhere domestically and over time, we inferred that epidemics are already growing exponentially in multiple major cities of China with a lag time behind the Wuhan outbreak of about 1–2 weeks." A quick calculation of predicted cases, based on a doubling time of 7 days and using today's official report figure of 28k, provides a value of 1.79 m by March 20. It is important to understand that this prediction is based on several important assumptions:
1) Changes in population behavior such as mandatory quarantine and self-isolation do not reduce the rate of spread
2) The reported number of cases is accurate
3) That the rate of spread (infectivity) remains the same, regardless of geography (e.g. urban vs. suburban vs. rural). Source: "Nowcasting and forecasting the potential domestic and international spread of the 2019-nCoV outbreak originating in Wuhan, China: a modelling study" Lancet Jan 31, 2020.

New update: the basic problem is estimating how the number of cases will evolve, and this requires to estimate how the current exponential growth will decelerate. There are 45 days approximately for the end of this question: conservatively it is difficult that the number is going doing below 50K, which I will use as a lower anchor. For the higher anchor, I will assume a deceleration of the doubling of cases as follows: today we have about 20K cases, about double the cases of 4 days ago, which are in turn the double of 7 days ago (so previously the doubling was then 3 days). Continuing this trend I notice that 5+6+7+8+9+10 = 45, giving me six doublings or about 1.3 M cases. But I will choose 0.8 M cases as a higher anchor to make the calculations easier. Now 50K x 16 = 0.8M cases. I will assume that the 50K to 0.8M range covers 98% of the possible outcomes for 20th of March. Now we notice that the errors compound geometrically, so I expect to have a log-normal distribution of cases by 20th of March. I will assume a mean of 200K cases, the one sigma band given by 100K-400K and the two sigma band given by 50K-800K. This gives me roughly the numbers above, except for the 1% that disappears below the 50K thresholds (which probably is really the minimum), which I move to the 200K+ bucket.

There are 60 days between the start date of the observations (2020-01-20) and the prediction date (2020-03-20). A rough approximation could be to divide the 60 days in three equal parts of 20 days and assume that the number of cases will follow an S-curve. This curve starts slowly (20 days), then has a steady linear part (20 days) and then it goes to its final steady value after another 20 days. (This assumption is probably on the safe (low) side). Concave upward part of the S-curve (20 days)
At the moment (Sitrep 13) we have 14557 cases. New cases are still growing at a rate of about 217/day/day. In Situation Report 14 I would expect about 14557 + (217*14)= 17595 cases in total. For Situation Report 15 the number should be 17595 + (217*15) = 20850. If the concave part of the S-curve lasts for 20 days we will end up on 2020-02-09 with 40380 cases. At that date the rate of change will be 4340 extra cases per day. Linear part of the S-curve (20 days)
I now assume that for the next 20 days the number of cases rises at the same rate as on 2020-02-09 (4340 new cases per day). This will add another 20*4340=86800 cases bringing the total to 127180. Concave downward part of the S-curve (20 days)
I assume that this will be a copy of the upward part, adding another 40380 cases. The grand total is now 167560 cases. I think my assumptions are erring on the low side. I am particularly intrigued with the number of cases in India (at the moment 2). If this starts to increase then we are in real trouble. So at the moment my estimate is in the region of 100k to 200k, but it could go well above 200k.

Over the last 3 days the reported  rate of growth of infections in China has slowed from 26% to 20%. If this trend continues the total would reach 50,000 around 8th Feb and 100,000 by around 13th Feb and 200,00o by around the 20th Feb. If the rate slowed to an increase of 10% per day it would still reach 200,000 before 20th March. Of course the increase of infection could flatten off, stop or increase.  It is worth noting that now person--to- person infections have occurred  in several countries and that an infection may not be noticed for two weeks its is possible that there are other countries than China where the outbreak has not been noticed. Several universities have used predictive models that suggest the actual number of infected people is far higher than reported. For example Imperial College London estimated that the 440  reported infected on 21st Jan could be 4,400 actual infections based on an average of 10 days from infection to symptoms. The Lancet published that rather than the 1,975 confirmed cases by the 25th Jan the true number infected could be 75,815 as at 25th Jan. In that case the true number could already be over 200,000. It should also be noted that this question will be answered by what the WHO says the figure is on 20th March, which itself may be subsequently  changed.

As of today there are 17318 cases. As the number of cases increases, the growth pattern emerges, and as there are more cases, the growth rate of the most recent three or four days is probably more accurate than previous days, because of the sample size. Over the last few days the growth rate has been around 20% per day.   If that continued, it would rise to over 100 million before 20 March. However, the growth *increase* seems to be slowing by about 8%. If that continued then there would only be about 150,000 by March 20.  I am guessing that the slowing of the increase will also slow. If it slowed by 7% instead of 8%, then it would still be over 200,000.

Data for Wuhan coronavirus infection and fatality cases are obtained from Wikipedia for this question [1]. The data have been updated everyday. In the last 7 days (since 26 January), infected cases has been rising almost a straight line. A linear regression of the 7-day data shows a slope of 1898 cases per day [2].  One of the worst scenarios is the number of cases keeps rising at this rapid rate until 20 March.  This would lead to a total of 104919 cases.  I consider this scenario unlikely (and scary) as the rapid rate keeps its pace for 8 weeks.  At the height of the SARS outbreak, the number of infected cases increased rapidly for 2 weeks before tapering off [3].  (Two caveats for this "unlikely" scenario.  First is that closer examination of the data indicates that the rate of increase is getting faster, e.g. 2099 in 31 January and 2579 in 1 February.  This means the linear slope used in this model could be an underestimate.  Second is that while 8 weeks are much longer than the SARS rapid inflection peak rate, we have no idea whether the peak rate for the Wuhan coronavirus cases is here already.) A more plausible scenario (model) is having this rapid rise for 3 weeks (till 16 February), then drops to 75% of this high rate and maintain this rate till 20 March (i.e. for 5 weeks).  This would yield 89259 cases.   An even more conservative model is to have the 75% peak rate maintained for 2 weeks (till 1 March).  Then reduce the rate to 50% of the peak rate and maintain it till 20 March.  This scenario essentially assumes we are able to control its spreading by this time.  This scenario produces 80243 cases. I am using the above 3 scenarios for the forecast.  Since the numbers of cases for the later two scenarios are close to the boundary between two of the baskets, they can easily be increased to land in the basket of 100,000 to 200,000.  My forecast are 30% for between 10,000 and 200,000, 70% between 25,000 and 100,000, and 0% for the other 3 baskets.   Significant updates might be needed depending on the number of cases in the next couple of weeks.

[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/961874
[3] https://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/en/

Updating and now explaining my logic: 1) I need some anchor value, something to indicate when will the current outbreak begin to linearize. I will assume this value to be about 25000 cases, which is sort of low. 2) After that I will assume that it is perfectly possible to double the number of cases from that to 50000. 3) I will assume that this is sort of a lower bound and that the possible distribution of number of cases in two months will be log-normal. 4) Being conservative, I could assume an upper bound of 500 000, about 10 times more. However 5M could be more realistic as the upper error estimate. This gives me a log-normal distribution where 68% of the cases lies between 50K and 500K cases, but I remove the lower tail of the distribution to account that the 25K mark will likely be reached. This results in the previous buckets.

Although the people in the affected area will (presumably) be avoiding crowded places it would seem (to me) unlikely that  people would be dressing up with full masks and goggles, washing hands frequently etc. when they mix with their families and close friends, who are symptom free. Given the gap between infection and symptoms appearing it can be assumed that there are between 20,000 and 50,000 people who have the virus but not the symptoms, these people will be passing on the virus, but hopefully to fewer people than they would have if the Shutdown had not been introduced. The next week will indicate if this is true or not. After the number of infected people reaches a certain level it exceeds the capacity of the health care system to isolate and treat the infected. I don't know what the capacity in Wuhan is or will be, but it can seen what happens to flu outbreaks. In 2009 a Flu virus spread to over 500,000 (lab confirmed cases with over 6,000 deaths. Following that outbreak I took part in a large scale research project on flu and flu like viruses, the research discovered that there was a huge range of effect, some people had no or almost no symptoms but had the virus while other people were very ill. So without taking random samples of people (as the research project did) it is impossible to establish how many people are infected or to isolate infected people. Its possible that the 2019-n-CoV is similar. If so it is likely that it will just become another of the cold and flu like viruses that are in the background population.

I agree the @Dillyweed approach.  Currently the number of cases is increasing very fast. I am assuming the rate of increase in the number of cases, which is currently around 40% a day, will drop, This is because (presumably) many infected people had assumed they what was ailing them was flu if they were not seriously ill, but now infected people  have been added to the 2018-nCoV diagnosis. If the increase in diagnosed cases drops to 25% (which could be a reasonable guess) after 10 days the number of diagnosed people would increase 10 fold. So 3K becomes 30k by around 7th feb, 300k by 17th Feb. As it takes up to 14 days for the symptoms to show, my guess is that there are already 30,000 infected people who don't yet know they are infected. Hopefully the infection rate will slow, but it is likely that there are now infected people with no symptoms spread all over the world in cities that don't yet know they have any infection and these infected people are spreading the virus world wide.   Hopefully my forecast is wrong and I would be pleased to read any comments showing me why I am wrong!

There were just under 8,100 confirmed cases of SARS in 9 months (11/02 - 7/03). That equates to an average of 900 a month. Currently there are 11.5k confirmed and suspected cases. The question just focuses on confirmed cases (4.5k). Current cases are increasing 9x faster per month in the first months than the SARS average. This makes sense given Cornoavirus is in its early stages and diseases like this grow exponentially.  Factors that could make this disease spread faster:
- it’s more contagious
- China’s population is bigger, wealthier, and travels more
- the globe is more interconnected All these factors make a 3x increase in the number of cases relative to SARS reasonable, but greater than 12x seems like a stretch given what we know
New reveal shows there are already close to 6,000 cases. That makes projection to add about same in next 4-6 weeks.

Currently there are roughly 6k cases confirmed (with lab analysis) which presumably represents the majority of the serious cases. There are an additional 9k suspected cases and 60k people in quarantine. The number of confirmed cases has been following a steady exponential growth through yesterday (1/28 in china) and has been roughly doubling every 2 days. At current growth rate we will exceed 200k in about 12 days.  If that growth rate continues we will be far above 200k by 3/20. So the question is how long will exponential growth continue and what will happen after that? Given that the incubation period is >10 days that means that the countermeasures put in place recently won't make a difference for a few more days.  Even if transmission stopped today we would presumably end up >100k cases in the near term as more people are tested and people in quarantine test positive.

Some things to take into consideration: - The 2003 epidemic of SARS-Cov resulted in more than 8,000 cases, affected 26 countries, and killed 774 people (WHO data).  Since 2004, only a small number of cases have occurred as a result of laboratory accidents or, possibly, through animal-to-human transmission (Guangdong, China).  
https://www.cdc.gov/sars/index.html
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/28/coronavirus-vs-sars-health-experts-on-the-key-differences.html - Chinese health authorities confirmed that, as of today, the 2019 coronavirus outbreak had infected 4,515 people, with 106 reported deaths. (This means the virus has killed just over 2% of those who have been infected. 
Other assessments suggested fatality is 3-4%.
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/28/coronavirus-vs-sars-health-experts-on-the-key-differences.html.) - Most reports seem to agree it is still too early to tell how contagious and how lethal the 2019-nCov is. 

- Many don't trust the Chinese government transparency in sharing information on what is really going on (they did quickly make available the genome and other info related to the virus worldwide).  And others do not trust the Chinese gov's capacity to contain the virus from spreading.  - Markets plunged yesterday on fears of a pandemic and its effect on the world economy. 
But markets are recovering today after the WHO said that it is optimistic the Chinese government will contain the virus.  At the same time, researchers at Hong Kong University contradicted the WHO, assessing that the 2019-nCov could reach 150,000 infections DAILY at its peak. They used an assessment of infections doubling every 6.2 days for the 2019-nCov. -There are reports the 2019-nCov genome shows that it may have originated around October 2019 but it's been officially detected since December 2019. Hundreds of thousands of people left the Wuhan area for the Chinese new year before the alarm was raised about the virus spreading. Reports on origins, transmission, origination have all changed in the last few days. So there are indicators that the virus might not be as lethal and that there may be a lot more people with the virus than reported (those reported are for people tested and confirmed) but that those cases may be milder and have not raised the alarm.    From what we've been told so far, there's reason to believe 2019-nCov may be more contagious but less lethal than SARS Cov. The age of social media spreads information and misinformation, panic and conspiracy theories exponentially faster than SARS in 2003.  But this might also help people avoid getting the virus.  Not betting on any catastrophic event right now but would rather trust the WHO on assessing the crisis as things develop.

Latest from Nature: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-00154-w I'm taking the 1917 flu pandemic and the SARS pandemic of 2003 as bracketing the most likely outcomes. The 1917 pandemic was fuelled in part by WWI. It also was most common among adults, in contrast to typical versions of the flu nowadays, where children and the elderly are most likely to die. Also, in 1917 there were no antibiotics to treat secondary infections. Today secondary infection mortality should be much less.  Also, today we know much more about how to control the spread of pandemics. The SARS pandemic killed only some 800 people and sickened 8,000.  GIven the tens of millions of refugees living in harsh conditions, if in this short time 2019-nCoV could take root in some them, for example the one million Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh, we might top 200,000.  But this seems unlikely. Another factor that could reduce the likelihood of high numbers is reporting lag. Even if China were to have that many sickened, it is not in the interest of the government to report all cases. In addition, the ability to detect and document so many cases might be poor. COnsider also that so far, no children over age five have been diagnosed with 2019-nCoV. By comparison with the 1917 flu, a major factor appears to have been increased vulnerability of people who previously had suffered an infection by a certain other flu. So it could be the case that mostly adults are at high risk, and indeed only mostly adults living in or near Wuhan. In addition, cultural factors related to crowding and eating with chopsticks from shared dishes among family and friends could have heightened transmissibility. Currently the citizens of affected regions are now following recommended hygiene steps. That plus massive quarantine efforts conducted by a powerful central government could limit future cases.
